journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Effect of circular tool path on cutting force profile in micro-end-milling

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical and Materials Engineering, The University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, Canada
2Centre for Automotive Materials and Manufacturing, Industrial Materials Institute, National Research Council of Canada, London, Ontario, Canada

author-notes.corresp: *Life Prediction Technology Inc., Ottawa, Ontario, Canada K1J 9J1. email: banerjeea@lifepredictiontech.com

abstract.p: Micro-end-milling requires high spindle rotational speed to achieve effective material removal. This results in the requirement of tool stoppage or slowdown during a micro-end-milling operation, a deterrent to productivity and to part acceptability. A circular tool path geometry can avoid discontinuities in the tool movements leading to a more consistent and smooth material removal. However, optimal process planning for such a tool path will require detailed understanding of the chip-formation mechanism in circular end-milling. The cut geometry during end-milling along a circular tool path is often approximated as that of a linear tool path. Although this assumption works well for circular tool paths with higher tool path radius, this is not the case for lower tool path radius often used in micro-milling. In this study, the effect of circular tool path on the cutting force for varying tool path rotation angle, tool path radius, and feed rate is experimentally investigated. Systematic signal processing was applied to analyse the measured cutting force signal along linear and several circular tool paths. Qualitative as well as quantitative differences were observed in the cutting force profiles obtained using different tool path radii, tool path orientations, and feed rates. This implies the need for an improved chip thickness formulation dedicated to micro-end-milling with circular tool path rather than approximating it with formulations derived for linear tool path.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In micro-end-milling, a cutting tool with low tool diameter requires extremely high spindle rotational speed to achieve a realistic surface speed and enable a productive material removal rate. A high spindle rotational speed may lead to high feed rates which are required to be accommodated along the programmed tool path trajectory. However, first-order discontinuities in the tool path trajectory will necessitate tool slowdown and stoppages. These unwanted fluctuations in feed rates will lead to jerks in the machine tool structure and large variation in the material removal rate. These will result in inconsistent machining, deterioration of surface qualities, and even tool breakage. Therefore, end-milling along a circular tool path where a constant feed rate can be maintained along the tool path trajectory becomes useful especially for high-speed milling [1]. In this article, a time-varying cutter–part intersection was used to model the chip removal mechanism for conventional or macroscale end-milling. The miniaturization of the milling process with micron-level tool diameters and depths of cut make the material removal mechanism and output parameters of micro-milling quite different from those in macromilling. In spite of the difference in scale of the process, the need to separately consider the material removal mechanisms for end-milling along circular tool path trajectory has been identified and supported with the results in the above paper [1].

The combination of two circular tool path segments like a biarc and one circular tool path and one linear tool path segment [2] like an arc-spline would provide G1 continuity along the tool path. Such a tool path will be particularly useful for micro-end-milling operation with high spindle rotational speed. Moreover, higher order tool path can also be represented in terms of the biarc and the arc spline segments which can be implemented in commercially available Computer Numerical Control (CNC) interpolation techniques. Machining along these tool paths with a constant feed rate would also lead to consistent and smooth machining, and result in higher productivity.

Modelling of the material removal process in the end-milling operation becomes important for selecting optimal machining parameters for achieving a desired productivity under the process constraints. It is well accepted that due to the effect of minimum chip thickness, tc min [3], there is no material removal when the tool edge radius is smaller than the minimum chip thickness. The workpiece material undergoes an elastic recovery during tool–material interactions instead of any shearing of the workpiece by the tool. This makes the chip-formation process and its modelling during micro-end-milling more complicated than those in the case of conventional end-milling. A trochoidal-based analytical chip thickness formulation has been proposed [4, 5] for micro-end-milling. The effect of minimum chip thickness and runout has also been considered [5] while modelling chip thickness. A static chip thickness model [6] considering the minimum chip thickness effect, runout, and tool deflection has been proposed and validated with measured cutting force. A dynamic cutting force modelling has also been presented [7].

Although substantial work has been performed to model the chip formation in micro-end-milling, tool path geometry has mostly been ignored. The material removal processes during end-milling along circular and linear tool paths have been generally assumed to be similar. Now, the material removed in consecutive tooth passes determines the chip thickness and subsequently the resulting cutting force. Machining along a linear tool path traditionally assumes a circular or at best a trochoidal cutting tooth trajectory [8]. However, in cases of circular end-milling, the cutting tooth trajectory is an epitrochoid rather than a trochoid as in a linear tool path and shown in Fig. 1(a). Hence, the assumption of approximating the material removal along a circular tool path with a linear tool path may not hold true, especially for tool paths with a low radius, often encountered in micro-end-milling. Fig. 1
Comparison of end-milling along linear and circular tool paths with respect to: (a) cutting tooth trajectory and (b) material removal along the tool path

The in-depth study of material removal during circular micro-end-milling will require the complete understanding of the chip formation along the circular tool path as well as considerations of the material removal mechanism. The undeformed chip thickness during micro-end-milling cannot be measured but is usually quantified with cutting force arising due to the shearing of the workpiece material by the cutting tool. Due to the complexities involved in the modelling and the prediction of cutting force in micro-end-milling, experimentally measured cutting force is widely adopted as an indication of state of the material removal process. The authors of this article had undertaken an experimental study into the chip formation during circular micro-end-milling [9]. The variation of cutting force profiles measured with a piezo-stage along with the tool radius was observed. However, instantaneous cutting force measurement with dynamometer and detailed analysis of cutting force variations during circular micro-end-milling are required.

This article experimentally investigates the effect ofthe geometry of a circular tool path on the cuttingforce in the micro-end-milling operation. In Section 2, the difference between micro-end-milling along a circular tool path and a linear tool path and the parameters influencing the chip thickness formulation in circular micro-end-milling are discussed. In Section 3, the experimental setup and signal processing are presented to identify the effect of tool path geometry as well as feed rate on the cutting force in a circular tool path and compare it with those measured along a linear tool path. The results and analysis of the cutting force measurements for different tool path rotation angles, radii, and feed rates are detailed in Section 4. The observations of the experimental results, comparative study, and subsequent analysis are summarized and concluded in Section 5.

sec.title: 2 CIRCULAR TOOL PATH
sec.p: A circular tool path finds extensive application in situations where first-order tool path discontinuities are to be avoided. When a cutting tool removes material along a circular tool path, the tooth trajectory, and material removal process cannot always be compared to those of a linear tool path. The first distinction is that the cutting tooth trajectory is epitrochoidal for a circular tool path rather than trochoidal in the case of a linear tool path, as shown in Fig. 1(a). A trochoid is the path traced by the circumferential point on a rotating disk with its centre moving along a linear path, whereas an epitrochoid is the path traced by a circumferential point on a rotating disk with its centre rotating along a circular path. The trochoidal and epitrochoidal tooth trajectories are given in equations (1) and (2), respectively. (1) (2) where r is the tool radius, R the tool path radius, θ the tool rotation angle, and β the tool path rotation angle.

Figure 1(b) shows a comparison of both linear and circular end-milling operations with a constant radial depth while moving the cutting tool positions from P1 to P2. During linear end-milling, machined areas defined by the points (a, b, c) on the tool axis placed at different distances (da, db, dc) from the tool centre (O) are equal (Aabb′a′a = Abcc′b′b). However, for a circular end-milling with tool path radius (R) and centre C, it can be observed that Aabb′a′a < Abcc′b′b. Hence, the point elements at a, b, and c move at different speeds about the centre C during circular end-milling, whereas their speeds remain the same during linear end-milling.

Moreover, in circular end-milling, the instantaneous feed per tooth (f) does not remain constant to the programmed feed per tooth (f0) at the tool centre (O) as in the case of linear end-milling. It varies with the different tool path geometries, tool radii, engagement domains, and programmed values of f0. In general, linear end-milling can be considered as a variant of circular end-milling with R → ∞ and trochoidal tooth trajectories. It is a well-known fact that in linear end-milling, variation of the chip thickness is symmetrical about tool rotation angle (θ). In contrast, for circular end-milling, the variation of chip thickness is not symmetrical and depends on the tool path radius (R), tool path rotation angle (β), and feed per tooth (f).

To study the dependence of the cutting tooth trajectory on the tool path geometry, two consecutive (j − 1)th and jth cutting tooth trajectories are considered and shown in Fig. 2 in grey and black, respectively. The figure represents the up-milling of a circular slot cut with an entry angle of 0° and an exit angle of 180° for a two-fluted cutting tool. Two different coordinate systems are used and shown in Fig.2(a). The first coordinate system is the global system having X–Y axes with fixed origin at the circular tool path centre (C). The second coordinate system is a local system having X–Y axes with their origin at the instantaneous tool centre (O), which rotates about the point C. Different values of the tool path radius (R) with centre at point C in relationship with tool radius (r) are also selected. Figure 2(a) shows the case when R > r, where for any point N subtending a tool rotation angle of θN on the current jth tooth trajectory, there is a point M on the previous (j − 1)th tooth trajectory subtending a tool rotation angle of θM, such that the current jth tool centre ON is aligned to M and N. The chip thickness (tc) for the jth tooth pass and tool rotation angle θN can be represented by the distance MN. The amount of material removed between the two consecutive passes is shown in grey with feed per tooth distribution along the circular tool path radius (C–O) as shown by the solid arrows. Fig. 2
Epitrochoidal tooth profile for different tool path radii: (a) R > r, (b) R = r, and (c) R < r

Figure 2(b) and (c) shows the tooth cutting trajectories for the cases with R = r and R < r, respectively. Itcan be observed by comparing among figures (Fig.2(a) to (c)) that the nature of the feed per tooth variation along the tool axis CO is quite different. In Fig. 2(a) and (b), the entire engagement domain of the tool is between 0° and 180°, but at the entry point, tc is higher for R = r and it becomes zero at the exit point. In Fig. 2(c), tc starts even with higher values at the entry point and becomes negative before approaching the exit point (shown with the magnification). This phenomenon occurs due to the fact that near the exit point of the current tooth pass, there is no material left to be removed. This can be called as backward-cutting, where the current tooth is within the engagement domain but does not remove any material as the material has already been removed in the previous tooth cutting trajectory. Therefore, a simplified formulation of chip thickness (tc) for linear end-milling [8] depends on the feed per tooth (f), and tooth rotation angle (θ) is not always applicable for formulating tc in circular end-milling. Rather, a more comprehensive formulation of tc depending on f and θ as well as on tool path rotation angle (β) and tool path radius (R) will be required. Since the chip formation in micro-end-milling being quite complicated, an alternative to modelling the chip formation is required to measure it. As direct measurement of tc is not possible, the cutting force measured in micro-end-milling is employed to quantify the chip formation and means of comparing the linear as well as different circular tool paths.

sec.title: 3 EXPERIMENTATION
sec.p:
The difference in chip formation with respect to feed per tooth and chip thickness during linear and circular micro-end-milling was experimentally investigated by measuring cutting force. To study the effect of circular tool path on the cutting force, measurements were obtained along tool paths with different geometries and feed rates. This required acut pattern to be designed such that five different tool pathradii, ∞ (linear slot), 50, 5, 0.5, and 0.05 mm could be accommodated in a 5 × 5 mm 2 square piece, without tool retraction to maintain the axial depth of cut throughout the tool path and shown in Fig. 3(a). Fig. 3
Experimental setup: (a) cut pattern, (b) different components, and (c) tool edge radius

The experimental setup is shown in Fig. 3(b). The micro-end-milling experiments were carried out using a brass workpiece and a two-fluted AlTiN coated micro-end-milling tool with a diameter of 200 µm. The top surface of the workpiece was pre-machined to obtain a flat surface and to help maintain the axial depth of cut at 50 µm. Slot cutting was employed with three different feed rates 0.25, 1.00, and 3.00 mm/s and a spindle rotational speed of 30 000 r/min. The feed rates have been selected to cover typical feed rate ranges for micro-end-milling of brass and with consideration for the minimum chip thickness effect, whereas the spindle rotational speed has been selected based on the recommendation of the cutting tool manufacturer as well as to obtain reliable cutting force measurements with a low noise level. The tool edge radius (re), a critical factor in selecting the minimum chip thickness (tc min), was measured using a scanning electron microscope with a magnification of 500 times as shown in Fig. 3(c). The ratio of the minimum chip thickness to the edge radius depends on the frictional characteristics at the chip–tool interface, which should be determined experimentally. From a previous experimental study [10], the ratio of tc min and re was calculated using the following equation [10] (3) where βf is the friction angle between tool and the chip. Using βf = 0.2 for HSS tool and brass workpiece [10], tc minre=0.23, which has been rounded off to 0.25. Material removal was also achieved for ratio of the edge radius to the maximum chip thickness being 0.1–0.2 [11].

A three-axis micro-machining system equipped with a Delta Tau™ motion controller and an electro-mechanical spindle (KaVo™) having a maximum rotating speed of 100 000 r/min was used for this study. The cutting force was measured using a pre-calibrated KISTLER piezoelectric dynamometer miniDyn Type 9256. A LabVIEW™-based data acquisition system was developed for real-time synchronous measurement of the analog and digital signals at sampling frequencies 25 kHz and 500 Hz, respectively. The analogue signals were the output voltages obtained from the three-component force dynamometer and the three phases of the spindle motor current. The square waves from XYZ position encoders were the measured digital signals. Further signal processing was carried out using MATLAB™.

In this study, the phases of the spindle current have been used to synchronize the cutting force component signals in each direction and to identify the tooth periods, as shown in Fig. 4. In order to quantify the shape of the cutting force profiles, the followingterms have been introduced and shown in Fig. 4:
AF+: It is the maximum positive amplitude of the cutting force profile.
AF-: It is the maximum negative amplitude of the cutting force profile.
AF : It is the absolute difference between the maximum positive and negative amplitudes of the cutting force profile. Based on the phase current signals and the terms AF+, AF-, and AF calculated from the measured cutting force signals, it was possible to identify and study the profile of the cutting force components corresponding to each tool rotation. The change in these terms suggested change in the cutting force profiles for different geometric and machining parameters. As mentioned earlier, it can be seen in Fig. 2 that the chip thickness during circular end-milling may not be symmetric along the tool rotation, and its variation also changes with the tool path radius and rotation angle. This would lead to variation in the cutting force profiles over each tool rotation and can be represented in the variation of the calculated AF values. Higher AF value will suggest higher asymmetry in the two cutting force profiles over a single tool revolution. Also, asymmetries arising from tool deflection and runout can also be quantified and observed. Fig. 4
Typical cutting force and spindle current profiles during micro-end-milling

sec.title: 4.1 Comparison of circular and linear tool paths
sec.p:
In this section, the cutting force signal for a slot cut measured along circular and linear tool paths with feed rate fr = 0.25 mm/s are compared. The amplitudes of the cutting force components along X (AFX) and Y (AFY) directions as well as their resultant (AFR) during micro-end-milling along a circular slot with tool path radius, R = 0.5 mm, and a linear slot cut were estimated. The original signal (FX, FX) and calculated amplitudes (AFX, AFY, AFR) for circular and linear slot cuts are presented in Figs 5 and 6, respectively. It can be observed in Fig. 5(a) that the cutting force components FX and FY are changing along withthe tool path angle, β. The variation can be understood by considering the tool rotational angle-dependent thrust and radial components of the cutting forces and their projections in the X and Y directions, which change along with β. Higher AFY for β greater than 90° observed in Fig. 5(b) may be attributed to a higher tool deflection in Y direction and simultaneous movements of machine tool axes having unequal rigidities in different directions. Fig. 5
Measured cutting force along circular slot (R = 0.50 mm, fr = 1.00 mm/s): (a) components along X and Y directions, and (b) calculated amplitude of components along X and Y directions and their resultant Fig. 6
Measured cutting force along linear slot (fr = 1.00 mm/s): (a) components along X and Y directions, and (b) calculated amplitude of components along X and Y directions and their resultant

In a linear slot cut, the measured cutting force components along X and Y directions and the calculated amplitudes remain relatively consistent over the entire tool path distance as shown in Fig. 6(a) and (b), respectively. The difference in the cutting force profiles for a circular slot cut and a linear slot cut is evident when Figs 5 and 6 are compared. The above differences in the cutting force components mostly arise from the effect of variation in the chip formation dependent on the tool path rotation angle and radius during circular micro-end-milling. Moreover, the minimum chip thickness criteria and asymmetry in the variation of chip thickness over tool rotation alsomake the material removal in circular milling more intermittent than in linear milling. This givesrise to a higher calculated AF during circular micro-end-milling as the tool may remove more material in one tooth period compared to other ones, which significantly increases the difference between AF+ and AF-. The variations in the cutting force profiles observed in Figs 5 and 6 suggest that the approximation of chip formation in circular end-milling with that in linear end-milling may not be true. Hence, there is a need for improved modelling of chip formation in circular end-milling. It should consider the tool path rotation angle and radius along with the feed and the tool rotation angle used in modelling the chip formation in linear end-milling.

sec.title: 4.2 Effect of tool path angle
sec.p:
The effect of the tool path rotation angle (β) is studied by comparing the cutting force components measured in the X and Y directions over five typical tool rotations with circular and linear slot cuts. The radius of the circular tool path is R = 0.50 mm and the feed rate for both the slot cuts fr = 1.00 mm/s. In addition to the global synchronization of cutting force components with the spindle current phase, the cutting force signals in the X and Y directions for circular slot cuts are locally synchronized. The comparison of the synchronized cutting force profiles for the circular slot cut with β = {0°, 90°, 180°} and the linear slot cut is shown in Fig. 7(a). The variation in the cutting force profiles during circular milling is observed along with the tool path rotation angle. This is primarily due to the difference in chip formation caused by the change in β as well as the movement of machine tool axes. Further, if the rigidity of the machine tool axes along the X and Y directions are different, simultaneous axis movements during circular micro-end-milling will also contribute to the difference. The correlation between the cutting force components in the X and Y directions for circular slot cuts with different values of β {0° to 180° with step of 15°} compared to a linear horizontal slot cut is shown in Fig. 7(b). The coefficient of correlation (ρ) is a measure commonly used to quantify the correlation between two measured variables (say x and y) and it is calculated based on the following equation [12] (4) where cov(x,y) is the covariance of x and y and σx 2 and σy 2 their variances, and the covariance is given by (5) which is the expectation of the vector product of the (x-x¯)(y-y¯) and x¯ and y¯ the means. Fig. 7
Measured cutting force along linear and circular slots (R = 0.50 mm fr = 1.00 mm/s) for different tool path angles: (a) profiles of components along X and Y directions, and (b)calculated correlation coefficients along X and Y directions

For β = 90°, the correlation between a circular slot cut and a linear slot cut is observed to be the highest for both along the X and Y directions. It is also the region where the possible deviations in the cutting force profile introduced by the simultaneous movements of machine tool axes during circular end-milling are minimum. This implies that the approximation of chip formation along a circular path with the chip formation along a linear path may be valid for only specific range of β. This range will depend on the value of the tool path radius and structural characteristics of the machine tool.

sec.title: 4.3 Effect of tool path radius
sec.p:
In this section, the effect of tool path radius on the cutting force profile in circular micro-end-milling isstudied. The tool path radius (R) is the most important parameter that distinguishes a circular end-milling from a linear end-milling operation. Although linear end-milling with R = ∞ is an extreme case of circular end-milling, the wide range of geometrically possible values of R makes chip formation in circular end-milling quite different. In this study, three different values of tool path radius R = 0.050, 0.50, and 5.00 mm, have been selected to represent a typical range for realistic circular micro-end-milling. The measured cutting force profiles for five typical tool rotations with fr = 1.00 mm/s at β = 45° and tool radius of 100 µm are shown in Fig. 8(a). The cutting force profile for a linear micro-end-milling is also shown by a dotted line for comparison. The deviation between the profiles for circular and linear tool paths is evident, with the profiles corresponding to R = 5.00 mm having the maximum amplitude. To study the profiles shown in Fig. 8(a) in more detail, the average and standard deviation (σAF) of the amplitudes of the cutting force components (AFX, AFY) and their resultant (AFR) are calculated and shown in Fig. 8(b). This figure clearly shows the increase in the average value of AF for both the X and Y directions with the increase of R and suggests a lower material removal for lower R. This can be explained by considering the decrease in the material removed in each tooth rotation as a function of the feed per tooth variation and the engagement domain. Both of these decrease with R as explained earlier and shown in Fig. 2. The back-cutting phenomenon will be responsible to further lower AF for the case with R = 0.050 mm where geometrically R < r. However, the value of σAF is observed to decrease with an increase in R. This may be attributed to more consistent machining for higher R, where the chip thickness is mostly greater than the minimum chip thickness and leads to material removal rather than rubbing of the tool against the workpiece. Fig. 8
Measured cutting force along linear and circular slots (fr = 1.00 mm/s and β = 45°) with different tool path radii (R = 0.05, 0.50, and 5.0 mm): (a) profiles of components along X and Y directions, and (b) calculated average and standard deviation of AF of components along X and Y directions and their resultant

To demonstrate the similarity of the circular andlinear end-milling for high tool path radius, cutting force profiles at different tool path angles β = {88°,90°, 92°} for a slot cut, with R = 50 mm and fr = 1.00 mm/s, are compared to those of a horizontal slot cut in Fig. 9(a). The range of β is selected such that the deviation in the force profiles introduced by the movement of machine tool axes is minimized. Avery close resemblance between the force profiles for circular and linear end-milling is observed. It is further supported by the high calculated coefficient of correlation as shown in Fig. 9(b). This reiterates that the linear end-milling is a special case of circular end-milling when R → ∞. Although it suggests that the modelling of chip formation for linear end-milling can be used to approximate circular end-milling, it is used only for high R. For lower values of R frequently used in micro-end-milling, a more accurate chip-formation model needs to be developed. Fig. 9
Measured cutting force along linear and circular slots (R = 50 mm, fr = 1.00 mm/s) with different tool path angles (β = 88°, 90°, 92°): (a) profiles of components along X and Y directions, and (b) calculated correlation coefficients along X and Y directions

sec.title: 4.4 Effect of feed per tooth
sec.p:
In this section, the cutting force profiles for circular slot cut with R = 0.50 mm and β = 90° with different feed rates are compared. In Fig. 10(a), typical cutting force profiles measured over five tool rotations are shown for different feed rates. It is observed that with increase in feed rate, the maximum amplitudes of the cutting force values also increase, suggesting a direct correlation. This observation is quite intuitive, as a higher feed rate means a higher material removal rate which would result in higher cutting force. In Fig. 10(b), the average and standard deviations, σAF of amplitudes of measured cutting force along X and Y directions, AFX and AFY as well as their resultant, AFR, are shown. The average AF increases with feed rate similar to the observation in Fig. 10(a). The σAF is also observed to increase with feed rate and can be attributed to a higher tool deflection arising from the higher generated cutting force. Fig. 10
Measured cutting force along circular slots (R = 0.50 mm and β = 90°) with different feed rates (fr = 3.00, 1.00, and 0.25 mm/s): (a) profiles of components along X and Y directions, and (b) calculated average and standard deviation of AF of components along X and Y directions and their resultant

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
Micro-end-milling along circular tool path can potentially avoid feed rate variation and machine tool stoppage during material removal and result in smoother and more efficient operation. However, determining optimal machining parameters for circular micro-end-milling would require an understanding of chip formation along the circular tool path. In this study, the chip formation in circular micro-end-milling has been experimentally studied by analysing the measured cutting force. At first, the need for studying and developing a separate modelling for chip formation in circular micro-end-milling operation is addressed by comparing it with linear end-milling. An accurate model would require the use of epitrochoidal cutter tooth trajectory which makes the chip formation dependent not only on the feed per tooth and tool rotation angle as in the case of linear end-milling, but also on the tool path radius and rotation angle. The cutting force has been selected to quantify the chip formation and measured during micro-end-milling of a brass workpiece with an AlTiN-coated tool. Measurements were obtained for different tool path radii, tool path rotation angles, and feed rates. The major conclusions of the comparative study of linear micro-end-milling and circular micro-end-milling with different tool path geometries and feed rates, by analysing the measured cutting force and calculated amplitudes, are given as follows:
The difference in the measured cutting force profiles in micro-end-milling along a circular tool path and a linear tool path is clearly observed. It arises from the variation of the cutting force components along X and Y directions and simultaneous movements of the machine tool axes during circular end-milling.
It is observed that the measured cutting force profile in circular micro-end-milling changes with the tool path rotation angle. At around 90°, the correlation between the profiles along a circular tool path and a linear tool path is the highest, suggesting a range where the chip formation in circular end-milling could be approximated with a linear end-milling.
The lower tool path radius results in lower measured cutting force amplitudes because of the lower engagement domain and material removal. For higher tool path radius greater than the tool radius, a complete engagement domain results in higher force. The cutting force profiles for circular micro-end-milling with a tool path radius of 50 mm were found to be close to those measured along a linear tool path. The effect of intermittent material removal is also observed at lower tool path radius which may arise from the minimum chip thickness effect.
The increase in the feed rate is proportional to the increase in the cutting force amplitudes. The effect of tool deflection was also observed for higher feed rates.

The above observations suggest major differences in the cutting force profiles measured in circular andlinear micro-end-milling. The approximation of chip-formation models in circular micro-end-milling with those developed for linear micro-end-milling will usually result in higher simulated cutting force values, especially for lower tool path radius. This indicates the need for a separate consideration for chip formation in circular end-milling especially for lower tool path radius which is common in micro-end-milling.

As a future work, an analytical chip thickness model for circular micro-end-milling will be developed by considering an epitrochoidal cutting tooth trajectory as well as the partial elastic recovery of the workpiece material and the minimum chip thickness effect. The model can be applied to simulate the cutting force in circular micro-end-milling and can be validated with experimental measurements similar to the ones presented in this study.

The financial support was also provided in part by Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada.

def.p: amplitude of cutting force per tool rotation
